Therefore, in all these things, the perpetual and infallible catholic doctrine remains that believers are justified and saved by faith alone or by the grace of God alone.

We return, therefore, to good works, which cannot be called good unless they are born of God through faith. If, however, they arise from God through faith, they are also formed according to the rule of the word of God; therefore, I added in the description of good works that they are done by those reborn from the good Spirit of God through faith and according to the word of God. For God does not approve of works that we contrive from ourselves.

For He approves obedience, but disapproves of good intentions born in us. This we demonstrate with these testimonies of the scriptures. In Deuteronomy, the Lord expressly commands in these words: "You shall not do as we are doing here today, every man doing whatever is right in his own eyes. Whatever I command you, be careful to observe it; you shall not add to it nor take away from it" [Deut 12:8, 32]. Furthermore, in the history of Samuel, a memorable example of this matter is set forth. For the king of the Israelites, Saul, receives the command to strike the Amalekites and all the possessions of the Amalekites with a ban. However, through good intention and chosen religion, he reserves the fatter cattle for a sacrifice to God, but hears from the prophet: "Has the Lord as great delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of the Lord? Behold, to obey is better than sacrifice, and to heed than the fat of rams. For rebellion is as the sin of witchcraft, and stubbornness is as iniquity and idolatry" [1 Sam 15:22f].

In these few words, you have an excellent encomium of chosen religion and works born from our good intention. Those who neglect the commandments of God and follow their good intentions are called magicians, apostates, and idolaters from the truth. They indeed seem to themselves to be excellent worshippers of God and zealous followers of the observances of the holy fathers, bishops, kings, and princes, but God, who cannot lie, expressly declares that their works are no different from magic, apostasy, and idolatry, than which nothing can be imagined more atrocious. Therefore, in the gospel, the Lord, from the prophecy of Isaiah the prophet, once condemns, rejects, and tramples underfoot all those chosen works born from our good intentions, when He says: "In vain they worship Me, teaching as doctrines the commandments of men. Every plant which My heavenly Father has not planted will be uprooted. Let them alone. They are blind leaders of the blind" [Matt 15:9, 13f]. Hence, it is that St. Paul with such confidence declared that the commandments of men are contrary to the truth and are lies. Elsewhere, the same one says: "Whatever is not from faith is sin" [Rom 14:23]. And again: "Faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of God" [Rom 10:17]. From which it can be gathered that works not formed from the word of God through faith are not only not good but are also called sins. To the Colossians, he most clearly condemns ἐθελοθρησκείαν, which the interpreter translates as "superstition," when it should have been translated as "voluntary and self-imposed religion." It is therefore evident from all these things that we do not condemn or oppose truly good works when we condemn and oppose the works of monks and priests, born of human choice and good intention outside the word of God. For it is now evident that those are not truly good works which we contrive from ourselves, but only those which God has commanded us. This will become even clearer from these words of St. Paul: "We are created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared beforehand that we should walk in them" [Eph 2:10]. He places two marks of truly good works. The first: "We are created in Christ Jesus for good works." Therefore, a good work must be done by one who is grafted into Christ Jesus. For unless the branch remains in the vine, it cannot bear fruit. We are grafted into the vine, Christ, by faith. The second: The works are not just any works or of any kind, but those which God prepared beforehand that we should walk in them. But what those are, He has expressed in His law, which is the will of God. Hence, when asked about eternal life and true virtues in the gospel, the Lord refers to the law and says: "What is written in the law?" [Luke 10:26]. And: "If you want to enter into life, keep the commandments" [Matt 19:17]. Therefore, the Decalogue is the most certain and absolute formula of good works; to understand this more fully, I will demonstrate this whole thing as if on a tablet with a brief enumeration. To the first commandment, you will refer the fear of God, trust and love, and finally, the most certain hope in adversity, patience, and unbroken constancy. To the second pertains true and sincere worship, which pleases God, and the denial of all superstition and perverse divine worship. To the third, reverence for the divine name, confession, invocation, and sanctification of the same. In the fourth, there will be a place for the moderate preservation of ecclesiastical ceremonies, the preaching of the word of God, public prayers, and whatever pertains to external worship. To the fifth, you will refer piety towards parents, country, and relatives, just obedience owed to the magistrate, and the duties of civil life. You will add to the sixth justice and judgment, the defense of widows and oppressed orphans, beneficence, and innocence. To the seventh, you will count marital fidelity and the duties of marriage, the liberal and pious education of children, and the pursuit of chastity, temperance, and sobriety. To the eighth, you will refer justice in contracts, liberality, munificence, hospitality. To the ninth, the pursuit of truth throughout life, faith in words and deeds, composed, honest, and useful speech. In the tenth place, you will recount good affections and holy vows, and finally, all holy and honest thoughts. This, indeed, is the concise formula of good works. But if you desire something more succinct, listen to the Lord in the gospel saying: "You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your mind, and your neighbor as yourself. And whatever you want men to do to you, do also to them" [Matt 22:37-39; 7:12].

Let all the faithful who desire to do good works direct their eyes and minds to these commandments of the Lord, and the more diligently and constantly, the more certainly they see and understand that God requires nothing else and no other works from His own in the law and the prophets. I can prove this with the most manifest testimonies of the greatest prophets. Moses in Deuteronomy says: "And now, Israel, what does the Lord your God require of you, but to fear the Lord your God, to walk in all His ways, to love Him, and to serve the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul, to keep the commandments of the Lord and His statutes which I command you today" [Deut 10:12f]. King David also asks in Psalm 15: "Lord, who may dwell in Your tabernacle?" [Ps 15 (Vulg. 14), 1] and immediately answers: "He who walks uprightly and works righteousness" [Ps 15 (Vulg. 14), 2] and the rest, which are contained in the Decalogue. The prophet Isaiah, asking the same question, says: "Who among us shall dwell with the devouring fire?" [Isa 33:14] and answers: "He who walks righteously and speaks uprightly" [Isa 33:15] and the rest, which are found in the Decalogue. Jeremiah in chapter 22 urges and presses these things: "Thus says the Lord: 'Execute judgment and righteousness, and deliver the plundered out of the hand of the oppressor. Do no wrong and do no violence to the stranger, the fatherless, or the widow, nor shed innocent blood in this place'" [Jer 22:3]. Nor does Ezekiel in chapter 18 list other good works in a long catalog. In Hosea, the Lord says: "I desire mercy and not sacrifice, and the knowledge of God more than burnt offerings" [Hos 6:6]. Micah also asks what he should do or with what works he should merit the Lord, and from the revelation of God, he answers: "He has shown you, O man, what is good; and what does the Lord require of you but to do justly, to love mercy, and to walk humbly with your God?" [Mic 6:8]. Similarly, the prophet Zechariah, when asked about virtue and works that please God, answers: "Thus says the Lord of hosts: 'Execute true justice, show mercy and compassion everyone to his brother. Do not oppress the widow or the fatherless, the alien or the poor. Let none of you plan evil in his heart against his brother, and do not love a false oath, for all these are things that I hate,' says the Lord" [Zech 7:9f; 8:17]. The prophetic doctrine does not differ from the evangelical and apostolic doctrine, which everywhere teaches charity, justice, and innocence, the goal and sum of all good works. I have proposed these things so copiously and with so many testimonies of the scriptures, lest anyone should henceforth either doubt or be ignorant that those alone are good works which are done from the good Spirit of God through faith and according to the scripture or the word of God.

It remains that we strengthen and explain with the comparison of scriptures what we have appended to the end of the description of good works. I have said that truly good works are done by the reborn for the glory of God, the adornment of life, and the benefit of the neighbor.
For the Lord, prescribing this end to our good works in Matthew, says: "Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works and glorify your Father in heaven" [Matt 5:16].

The Apostle Paul also, not once, in exhorting to good works, appends that which can most move, that in all things they may adorn the doctrine of our Savior with their works of piety. Now, just as a decent and honest garment adorns a man, so truly good works commend the life of men.

Hence, the apostles of Christ have so often advised to put off the old man and put on the new, who is created according to God. From this, glory and honor come to us. We are called and are servants, indeed children of our God, whose nature and virtue shine in us to the glory and praise of His name.

Moreover, He increases His gifts to us who do well more and more, since He said: "To everyone who has, more will be given, and he will have abundance. But from him who does not have, even what he does not have will be taken away and given to him who has" [Matt 25:29]. Added to this is that God is favorable to those who do right and enriches them with many temporal gifts, and finally grants them eternal life. For the Apostle Paul expressly says: "God will render to each one according to his deeds, to those who by patient continuance in doing good seek for glory, honor, and immortality, eternal life" [Rom 2:6f]. And again: "Glory, honor, and peace to everyone who works what is good" [Rom 2:10]. Although in all good works the pious have not set a private gain as their goal, but the glory and will of God, and finally the benefit of the neighbor. For Paul says: "Do all to the glory of God" [1 Cor 10:31]. And: "Let no one seek his own, but each one the other's well-being, just as I also please all men in all things, not seeking my own profit, but the profit of many, that they may be saved" [1 Cor 10:24, 33]. Therefore, all the pious direct all their efforts and works to this end, that they may benefit many. For in this, they express the nature of God, whose children they are. For He desires to do good to all creatures, hence His children are beneficent and have beneficence as the sole goal of their life and efforts before their eyes.

This is what I have at present concerning the nature, character, cause, end, and effect, that is, the true and just reason of good works, from which I hope it can be especially understood how the name of righteousness and justification is attributed to the good works of the saints, and how the Lord is said to render a reward in the holy scriptures, and that the orthodox and primary doctrine of our religion remains immovable and firm: that we are justified by the grace of God for Christ's sake through faith, not by works. Now, therefore, nothing remains but that we pray to the Lord with constant vows for true faith in the Lord Jesus, by which we may be truly justified, and through the most fervent invocation of His name, we may put into practice the discussion held thus far about good works, that is, that we may express and adorn the faith we profess to have in our Lord Jesus Christ with truly good works, mindful of the words of Christ the Lord in His gospel saying: "Not everyone who says to Me, 'Lord, Lord,' shall enter the kingdom of heaven, but he who does the will of My Father in heaven. Many will say to Me in that day, 'Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in Your name, cast out demons in Your name, and done many wonders in Your name?' And then I will declare to them, 'I never knew you; depart from Me, you who practice lawlessness!' Therefore, whoever hears these sayings of Mine and does them, I will liken him to a wise man who built his house on the rock, and the rain descended, the floods came, and the winds blew and beat on that house; and it did not fall, for it was founded on the rock. But everyone who hears these sayings of Mine and does not do them will be like a foolish man who built his house on the sand, and the rain descended, the floods came, and the winds blew and beat on that house; and it fell, and great was its fall" [Matt 7:21-27]. Let us therefore strive with holy and constant prayers and true diligence of mind and piety, that we may be built upon the living stone, Christ Himself, as living stones, a living and enduring structure in all the assaults of various temptations, a spiritual house, a holy temple, and a sacred priesthood, offering to our Redeemer and Justifier, Jesus Christ our Lord, spiritual and most acceptable sacrifices, praises, alms, and our own bodies, and indeed ourselves and all that is ours.

Moreover, concerning faith and works, it will be discussed here and there and more extensively throughout this entire evangelical work of ours, which, in order that they may be more correctly and fully understood, I have wished to preface and thus far preface this as a compendium of justification and good works.

For as far as the manner of writing and my intention, which I have followed in this work of my commentaries, I will not deal with it at length. For I have explained most of it in the preface to Matthew, since I have aimed at the same things in this work as there. I have diligently read the expositions of both ancient and recent writers on the gospel according to John and have used them in their places, as I have candidly noted in my own work what I have borrowed or transcribed from whom. For I never wanted to imitate those, nor did I ever like the minds of those who, when they could use the pious and prudent writings of the ancients, prefer nevertheless to invent new things rashly without consulting or considering them and to bring forth into the light things little weighed. Moreover, it seemed to be a far more approved method to use the testimonies of the ancients and the strength of scripture in explaining the scriptures, especially in such a great dissension of doctrines, moderately, indeed, and almost continuously, so that even our adversaries may see openly that we do not establish our faith with our own or new doctrines brought in by new faith, but with the more ancient and confirmed opinions and expositions of the most holy churches, and thus to confirm our faith, which is the oldest of all, and indeed the only one, pure and simple and first. However, I have taken care, above all, that from our commentaries the context of the apostle's speech may be understood as clearly as possible, since there does not seem to be any method of exposition more evident and clearer than the diligent observation of the context of the speech; if this is neglected, I do not see how the mind of the writer and the genuine sense can be held.

I have divided the whole work into 10 books, prefixed arguments to each, in which I have outlined the sum and context of the matters, so that in the subsequent treatment everything would be clearer and the reader would have the goal constantly before his eyes, at which he should aim. I have asserted the orthodox opinion and exposition against distorted and corrupt interpretations throughout. I have also frequently refuted and opposed various errors. In all these my labors, I have wished to benefit the church of Christ and serve those who are zealous for the truth of the gospel. Meanwhile, I prejudge no one, I despise and belittle no one's labors. If anyone gives better things, I will not only not envy but will rather give thanks. But I also propose mine to be weighed according to the apostle's saying: "Test all things; hold fast what is good" [1 Thess 5:21].

These my lucubrations, written and published within 9 months, I have therefore decided to inscribe to you, Lavater, most esteemed lord and most faithful godfather, because there are many and great benefits from you to me and to all the ministers of Christ, and to stimulate your diligence more. You have hitherto loved and helped the Christian religion and the republic not in a common way.

When you were acting as prefect or proconsul in that very large county of Kyburg, in the name of the council, senate, and people of Zurich, you promoted the affairs of religion and the republic with such faith for many years that even today the best people do not cease to praise your virtue. You favored the evangelical doctrine from the very beginning, when its first foundations were laid by Zwingli of blessed memory, the faithful pastor of our church. You had seen in Rome, sent as a legate by the most illustrious council and senate of Zurich together with the most distinguished Jacob Werdmüller, a man who greatly favored piety, how great the corruption of the priests and the whole papal religion was, and therefore you more easily joined the cause of Christ, the evangelical doctrine, I say. And in its confession and faith, you have hitherto persevered most steadfastly, even in that severe temptation of ours and in your greatest danger, when under your leadership and command, the battle was fought unfavorably at Kappel. Certainly, as the gracious Lord was never absent from you, so here especially He did not forsake you, who first indeed snatched you from that bloody and fierce battle and from the hands of the most fierce enemy while you were fighting bravely, and then defended you from the calumnies of certain envious people, while immediately after the war, the most holy senate of ours diligently inquired into the faith of your administration and conduct of the war because of the calumnies of some, and having thoroughly known all things, gave illustrious testimony to your virtue and innocence that nothing was neglected in that war through your fault, but that all things were administered by you with the best faith.

To which was added that later it increased and adorned you with public honors and dignities as well-deserved. Therefore, continue to be faithful to the liberal and munificent Lord, your liberator. Continue with all good people to help the evangelical cause and to propagate the kingdom of Christ as widely as possible, so that finally Christ, our King and Lord, may transfer you into His eternal kingdom to Himself and to the fellowship of all the blessed, when you are released from this mortal harbor. May the grace of the Lord be with you.
Zurich, in the month of August, in the year of our Lord 1543.
